reviewText: If you are not a fan of 1950's film noir, give this movie a pass. But if you like this genre, or just want to get to know it, this is a good movie for you. Wendell Corey, a young Elsa Lanchester, and Evelyn Keyes are parts of a very good cast. It is a mystery film with some nice twists and turns. A major character is actually Hawaii itself in the post-war period. I got a kick out of it. I found it at Amazon.
Title: N/A

reviewText: GOOD NOIR...ESPECIALLY SEEING HAWAII IN LATE 40'S AND EARLY 50'S...WENDELL COREY DOES A GOOD JOB AS AN EX-GANGSTER WHO IS CAUGHT IN A NOIR JUNGLE OF PROVING HIMSELF A WORTHY HUMAN BEING...EXCELLENT CAST BACKS COREY IN THIS THRILLER FROM THE PACIFIC.

reviewText: Image quality is good on this obscure Republic Picture. Hopefully Olive Films will be releasing more items from the Republic vault. I'd personally like to see good copies of the Stories of the Century TV show. As for this picture, it's good. The opening is fantastic!

reviewText: In the last few years, Olive Films has been doing an exceptional job in getting both high profile films(such as "High Noon", "The Quiet Man", "Body and Soul") as well as some obscure titles from the Republic Films catalog on Blu-ray for the first time. The results have been mostly positive so far. Many of the titles are in black and white and cover a wide range of subject matter. One such film is "Hell's Half Acre" a film noir set in Hawaii eleven years after the Pearl Harbor bombing. The film, released a year after Columbia's big Oscar winner "From Here to Eternity"(which also took place in Hawaii) covers the more seamy side of paradise that probably made the people at the Hawaiian Tourist Bureau wince. It's filmed film noir style and once it starts you get caught up in the plot. The film starts with a young widow(Evelyn Keyes) listening to a new record(vinyl) and hearing some lyrics of the song that sound very familiar to her. The lyrics are the same words that are written on a photo of her husband who was killed at Pearl Harbor. Or was he? That's all I'm going to say about the plot. The film itself has one of the best casts of characters you'll ever see. Besides the leads(Wendell Corey & Evelyn Keyes) we get Keye Luke & Philip Ahn(from "Kung Fu"), Elsa Lanchester("Bride of Frankenstein"), and even Jesse White and Marie Windsor as a most unlikely husband and wife team. Marie Windsor has only three scenes but she's great as usual. She's a favorite.  There are many location shots filmed on the beaches of Waikiki with Diamond Head in the background. If you look closely you can see Evelyn Keyes and Elsa Lanchester in an outrigger canoe with lots of surfers riding the waves along with them. Hawaii in the early fifties looks stunning on this new Blu-ray transfer from Olive. The Blu-ray itself arrives in a sturdy Blu-ray plastic case(not one of those terrible eco-cases) which is housed in a nice slipcase. The video quality is excellent. There are no vertical lines running through the picture and there is no noticeable debris. Olive used a very clean print for this Blu-ray and it shows, especially in the dark night scenes. Blacks, whites and grays are very consistent which bring out even the smallest details. This is very noticeable in close-ups of the actor's faces which bring out details of their faces that are not covered up with make-up, that's how clear the Blu-ray is. The team of restorers at Olive is to be commended once again for bringing the best product out for film collectors and consumers as well. If you purchased Olive's recent Blu-ray releases of "High Noon", "Rio Grande", and "Force of Evil" then you will certainly enjoy "Hell's Half Acre". Like other Olive releases this one has no subtitles and no special features. "Hell's Half Acre" might not be as well known as "From Here to Eternity" but it has some great Hawaiian locations and one other thing that the other lacks. It has Marie Windsor. She alone is worth the purchase price.
summary: FILM NOIR BLU RAY - HAWAIIAN STYLE
Title: N/A

reviewText: This one is labelled as "film noir," but as I was watching it I went back and forth on whether it should be considered "noir" or just a lurid piece of pulp. There are some canonical "noir" elements to be sure, as well as features that preclude such categorization. At the end of the day only purists will care.  Whether "noir" or not, this is a fascinating reminder that the 1950s were not all "I Love Lucy", MGM Musicals, Doris Day, and "Ozzie and Harriet."  You get a fascinating portrait of the seamy side of Hawaii in the post WWII years, with a focus on the Honolulu vice pit known as Hell's Half Acre.  True to some noir and race assumptions of the day, the film uses "exotic" locales and introduces white characters to a demi-monde of non-white people to add an air of presumed mystery and unseemliness to the story line. There are plenty of reminders of how in film suggested sleaze can make as much of an impression as overt sleaze.  Most of the acting is forgettable, but Elsa Lancaster and Marie Windsor are riveting. The night scenes in the Hell's Half Ace tenements are fantastic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is directed by John Auer, who also directed "The City That Never Sleeps," also available from Olive Films on blu ray.  The story revolves around two major events, one being that on Hawaii an ex-thug of sorts is being shaken down by his former companions in crime, resulting in his sweetheart's death; and that this ex-thug also sells songs(!) and has a popular record on the airwaves, when a stateside woman notices an uncanny ring of familiarity to the lyrics.  Like "The City that never sleeps," the cinematography is good, the sound is good, and it has enough atmosphere to be entertaining. However the clear reason to get both this and "The City that never sleeps" are summed up in two words: Marie Windsor.  If I hitch myself to a villainess or bad girl, I'd like Marie Windsor to play the part.  She is just a magnetic character in any of her movies.  This movie also has the reliable and interesting Wendell Corey, and Elsa Lancaster has a role as a cabbie. The only downside is once again Olive Films has nothing but the movie on this rather pricey blu ray -- not even subtitles or captions for the hearing impaired.
Title: N/A
